p: The analyses and identification following NMR spectroscopy of the Tagetes lucida essential oil revealed the presence of geranyl acetate (( E)-3,7-dimethyl-2,6-octadien-1-ol acetate) ( 1, Figure 1; see also Supplementary Materials) as the major compound ( Table 1), representing 50% of the total content. The NMR spectrum of this essential oil showed almost exclusively the diagnostic signals for the monoterpene ( 1): δ H 5.34 [1H, t, J = 8 Hz, H-2; δ C 118.2 (C-2)], and δ H 5.07 [1H, t, J = 8 Hz, H-6; δ C 123.7 (C-6)] signals for two vinyl protons; an allylic methylene group at δ H 4.59 [2H, d, J = 8 Hz, H-1; δ C 61.37 (C-1)]; two methylene groups at δ H 2.09 and 1.72 assigned to C-5 (δ C 39.5) and C-4 (δ C 26.26). At 2.04 ppm, a singlet (3H) was assigned to the methyl of an acetoxy group (δ C 171.0 and 21.2); three other singlets (3H each) at δ H 1.69, 1.67, and 1.59 were assigned to C-10, C-8, and C-9 methyl groups (δ C 16.4, 25.6 and 17.6), and two quaternary vinyl signals were recorded at δ C 142.2 (C-3) and δ C 131.8 (C-7). Its identity was confirmed based on spectral data (NMR and MS) and by comparison with reported values in the literature (AIST: Integrated Spectral Database System of Organic Compounds [ 15]).
